title: dyfri owen increase graffiti tagging penarth
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityDyfri Owen, director of PenarthPhysiotherapy Practice andPilates Studio, has had a sign advertising his studio, just off Victoria Bridge in the town centre tagged recently.ldquoThere seems to be signicantly more graffiti in our town recently,rsquorsquohe said.ldquoNot only does it look unsightly but there will be an expense to my small business to either clean it or replace it and small businesses are already struggling due to the pandemic.ldquoFortunately, most of it appears to be on derelict buildings and things like BT Openreach hubs rather than small business premises and residential houses.ldquoI will remove the graffiti from my sign and replace the signrequired because it obviously looks unsightly for our neighbours, spoils the aesthetics of the town centre and potentially has a negative impact on how my practice is viewed.The sign is just off Victoria BridgeldquoHowever, our sign can still be clearly read by our patients and potential future patients and in a way the perpetrator has successfully drawn more attention to myPhysiotherapy andPilates business as many people have contacted us to inform us about the vandalism and to pass on their commiserations.rsquorsquoMr Owen is aware that evenhe replaces the sign, there is the chance that this could happen again, but said: ldquoYou cannot spend your le worrying about that, you have to do the right thing for the appearance of the town centre.MORE NEWS:ldquoI do not feel angry towards the iniduals who are spraying graffiti all over Penarth town centre.ldquoI actually feel very sorry for them. They must live very boring, unfulfilling lives.     ldquoIt must be awfulthe most fun you can think of having and the most productive thing you can think of to do with your time is to sprayyour name on someone s property.ldquoWhen they eventually mature and develop a conscience, they will look back and regret the things they had previously done and the amount of time they wasted doing these selfish and unnecessarythings.rsquorsquoPenarthPhysiotherapy Practiceand Pilates Studio was established on Windsor Road in . It moved to The Courtyard in Penarth TownCentre in October .Its Director, Dyfri Owen has worked asPhysiotherapistto Cardf Rugby Club for the past  years and asPhysiotherapist to the Football Association of Wales for the past  years.They also provide Physiotherapist-led Pilates classes and they have created a large, loyal Pilates community within Penarth.Their Pilates classes have been on Zoom for the past year but they look forward to welcoming their clients back to the Courtyard Pilates Studio in the near future. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: cardiff grounds not location hinkley point dredging
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe dredger vessels ndash which were used during the first phase of dredging in  - are docked in Barry awaiting approval for to begin their work.EDF Energy, who are running the Hinkley Point C development, have confirmed they have booked the vessels in anticipation of a dredging and depositing licence being granted for Portishead but they have not made an application for a licence for this to be done in Cardf Grounds. If they do decide to make the application, it would go to a public consultation ndash which has been completed for Portishead.MORE NEWS:Grfin Books becomes Jhalak Prize Champion - what it means for the shopSome have called for Covid- vaccine to be mandatory for care home staffMore time to share views on the future of Penarth PavilionChris Fayers, head of environment at Hinkley Point C, said: "We have made an application to dredge and then deposit mud at Portishead and are awaiting a decision. We have also submitted an application for Cardf Grounds. The decision on which licensed disposal site will be used is driven by regulatory approval and project schedule."For this second phase of dredging, the UK Government marine scientic agencywent further than before, testing the mud beyond internationally recognised best practice, with more samples at greater depth and with a greater range of analysis. The results confirm previous analysis that the mud is perfectly safe for disposal at sea and poses no risk to humans or the environment."The vessels are arriving in preparation for our planned marine works. Works will only commence when the appropriate licences have been granted by the regulator." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: ruth dodsworth speaks abusive relationship morning
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityMs Dodsworth was stalked by her husband Jonathan Wignall, who jailed last week for three years.Speaking on ITVs This Morning about years spent being coercively controlled by Wignall, she said that the details of her case were never meant to be public."Suddenly they were out there when Jonathan was sentenced," she said."The decision to go public was almost taken away from me."The pair had been married for  years and Ms Dodsworth - a regular ITV weather presenter on regional news in Wales and London ndash said that "within a marriage, at first, you try to make it work"."You make excuses, you put on this smile," she said.However, she said that with the benefit of hindsight, all the signs were there."We were happy, but there were instances where his temper was obvious," she said."As things started to fall down, I became the focus of his temper, his anger."The very phrase lsquodomestic abusersquo or lsquocoercive controlrsquo I find quite dficult to say because, for a long time I didnrsquot recognise or put myself in that category."She explained that around two years ago things began to escalate signicantly."He had been phoning me hundreds and hundreds of times a day and turning up at the office," she said."One particular day he had started drinking early in the day. By the time my children got home from school they were phoning me saying ldquomum, donrsquot come home. Hersquos going to kill you."That was a turning point. I didnrsquot go home that night. If I had, I donrsquot think I would be here now."Ms Dodsworth explained how, while she was sleeping, Wignall, now of Trawler Road, Swansea, held her thumb on her phone so that he could gain access to it.He also stood outside the bathroom door while she was in there."To him, every male I met was a potential affair," she said.     "He offered to pay my children money to go into my phone."He put a tracker on my car, which we only noticed after he started turning up in places he had no reason to be."This is a man I loved, and who was father to my children."She said that it took someone  saying ldquoRuthyou donrsquot phone the police, I will, to change the situation."When yoursquore in that situation itrsquos degrading, dehumanising," she said."I wouldnrsquot be aliveI hadnrsquot asked for help." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: expect penarth pub gardens reopen monday
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityPub-goers have waited months for this day, and now they will be allowed to have a pint outdoors as coronavirus rates drop.Hayley Clare, bar manager, and Stephen Newman, chairman, at Penarth Athletic Club said that they have been lsquobusyrsquo setting up the outdoor pub garden ready for when they can welcome back customers and members on Monday.They will also be hosting a iety of local businesses to use their kitchen to cook food for those attending, such as Crepe Escape and Onzon Thai.Speaking about the past year, Ms Clare, who started working at the club in September of last year, said that they took the lockdowns as their opportunity to look at where they were, what they were doing and make some changes as there were some issues with parts of the building and they were granted the time to upgrade.Hayley and StephenThe current Welsh Government law only allows hospitality to open outside, and the club has a big space of green land to make use of which can host around  people - but only two households per table.Marquees are also being installed to create some shelter in case the weather decides to change.Mr Newman has described the past year as lsquomadnessrsquo, and that theyrsquod never realised lsquohow good a big gardenrsquo they had until coronavirus regulations made them.ldquoWersquore lucky we have so much space herersquo, he added.Table service will be the only option upon customers ing, as to not have so many people crowding a particular space wanting to order food or drink.The pub garden is being prepared for Monday ldquoTable service is ten times better than people going to the bar, and people like it, added Mr Newman.ldquoItrsquos a lot safer and lets us employ a lot more staff, as wersquove made more money from it.The club previously had one member of staff to help with the bar, now they have taken on .     Before the pandemic, Mr Newman says the clubs turnover would have been around pound,, but in the past year, from the success of their beer garden, that has turned into half a million.ldquoWe had two ways of looking at it - we could wait for things to happen, but instead we did something, he said.When asked about the Christmas lockdown on December , Ms Clare said it lsquowas neededrsquo.At the end of November last year, the seven-day coronavirus rate for Wales was  cases per , people but that then shot up to  cases per , by mid-December.The Welsh Government took unavoidable action to place Wales under Tier  restrictions and changed Christmas arrangements after receiving information about the spread of the iant in the country.ldquoYou could see it coming, addedMs Clare.ldquoYou almost donrsquot want to open when itrsquos like that anyway.Both say the Vale of Glamorgan Council have been lsquovery goodrsquo with providing grants to the club while they have been closed.ldquoWersquove had regular grants and only had to chase now and then but thatrsquos likely due to the number of businesses theyrsquore providing for, said Mr Newman.ldquoItrsquos kept us afloat.The benches were made by the rugby club members Both say they canrsquot wait for Monday but know that it is going to be a busy week due to them already being fully booked.ldquoItrsquos nice as wersquove been shut for such a long time. Itrsquos going to go from dead, to mental!The Deck at Penarth marina will also be reopening on Monday their Jetty Bar and Balcony.They have also installed a new canopy that covers the balcony area, ready for any and all-weather changes.There is limited space for bookings, so to find out more head towww.thedeckpenarth.Ben Coates, bar manager atPenarth Lawn Tennis Club, said everyone is lsquoreally excitedrsquo to be opening their club grounds to members again.Penarth Lawn Tennis Club pub garden. Picture taken before the pandemic. ldquoWe believe we have one of the best spaces in Penarth to offer members the opportunity to play and socialise, he added.ldquoWe have spent time organising the club grounds, so theyrsquore set up for maximum social distancing and have built a new outside bar to serve our members.ldquoNew members are welcome to the club and all information can be found on the clubs webpage:https:clubspark.lta.org.uk PenarthLTC.On The Rocks owner Steve,based in Sully, said: ldquoThe last fourmonths has been extremely dficult for all of us in this trade thats for sure, its long overdue that we can open all be it outside only!On The Rocks pub garden area. Picture: On The RocksldquoWe need to get back to some normality as soon as possible.ldquoOn The Rocks will be serving our great milkshakes snacks and coffee along with alcoholic drinks too until we can use inside again the food being served will be from the Seashore Grill.ldquoWe have a good outside space between the two restaurants with an amazing roof garden at the Seashore Grill also.For more information head to @ThePinkFloydBar on Facebook.Welsh Government guidance says that walk-ups should be kept to a minimum butthere is capacity and venue is allowing it, yes.Where possible pre-booking is recommended for pubs across Wales, with the details of all members of a group taken as part of the booking and checked by staff on arrival.Here are some other pub gardens that our readers recommended:The Railway, Plymouth RoadManor House, Sully RoadThe Oystercatcher, Terra Nova WayThe Captainrsquos We, Beach Road, SullyPickfords Galley  Bar with Rooms, The Esplanade article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: trussell trust show food bank use increase wales
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThat is according to the latest Trussell Trust report, which reveals foodbanks in its network across Wales handed out , emergency food parcels to people facing crisis between April  and March .These figures mark an eight per cent increase on the the previous year, when , parcels were handed out.It is also a  per cent increase since  .The Trust say these figures are just the tip of the iceberg, with a number of people being helped by other food aid providers and community groups that sprang up during the pandemic.Susan Lloyd-Selby, the Trussell Trustrsquos operations manager for Wales, said: ldquoNo one should#face the#indignity of#needing#emergency food."Yet our network of food banks across Wales continue to provide huge numbers of food parcels as more and more people struggle without enough money for the essentials."This#is not right#but#we know we can build a better future.#This pandemic has shown the unexpected can hit suddenly, but we know when we push for change, united by our desire for justice and compassion, the government#has to#listen and act.#ldquoWersquove welcomed an increased take up of the Discretionary Assistance Fund along with extended free school meal provision, but we must go further to ensure we all have enough money for essentials.ldquoWe are asking you, the public, to write to your Senedd election candidates for a commitment to working to end the need for food banks. Together we can take action now to build#a#hunger#free future for Wales.:Hunger in the Wales isnrsquot about food, the charity says, itrsquos about people not having enough money#for the basics and with#high rates of#unemployment#and#record#redundancies, more people than ever need the#social security#system to#provide a strong#enough#leline#to#stay afloat.##     Sabine Goodwin, coordinator of the Independent Food Aid Network added: "Independent food banks in Wales are also continuing to see relentless need for their help although combined Trussell Trust and independent food bank figures represent a fraction of the food insecurity picture."Now more than ever, our UK social security system needs to be reset, the Discretionary Assistance Fund promoted and prioritised and adequate wages and secure work ensured."Its the responsibility of governments to stop hunger from happening in the first place so that everyone is able to afford to buy food and other essentials." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: driving tests allowed wales today   need know
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityHowever, there are reports that, due to a signicant backlog, there could be a wait of up to seven months to rebookthe test is failed.This could add extra pressure to an already nervous situation.We have compiled a list of all you need to know should you be thinking of booking your test asap.What will happenmy driving test is affected The Driver and Vehicle Standards Agencywill contact youyour test is affected and tell you what you need to do.How can I book my test You can still book your driving test online hereDo I have to wear a mask Yes, unless you have a good reason not to.When you arrange your test, yoursquoll need to saytherersquos a good reason you cannot wear a face covering when you take your test.This includes :- you have a physical or mental illness or impairment, or a disability that means you cannot put on, wear or remove a face covering- putting on, wearing or removing a face covering would cause you severe distress- you need to remove it during your test to avoid harm or injury or the risk of harm or injury to yourself or othersWearing glasses does not count as a good reason not to wear a face covering. You should practise driving wearing a face covering before your test to help you prepare.You might not be able to take a test at your preferred test centreyou cannot wear a face covering.IMPORTANT - Your test will be cancelledyou come for your test without a face covering and you did not declare you could not wear one when you arranged your test.Driving examiners will be wearing face coverings - they might also choose to wear gloves and use disposable seat covers.Driving instructors will not be permitted to sit in the back during your test.If you have a problem with your face covering during the test, your driving examiner will ask you to stop so you can adjust it. Your driving examiner will end the test earlyit becomes a safety issue.     Do I have to take a coronavirus test first The government have said that itrsquos best to take a rapid lateral flow test before your driving testyou do not have COVID- symptoms and yoursquore in:- England- Wales, and you cannot work from homeFor more information on the lateral flow test, click hereWhat should I do on the day Do not arrive for your driving test more than five minutes before your appointment time.Some driving test centre waiting rooms are closed to help prevent the spread of COVID-. Your driving instructor or accompanying driver can checkthe waiting room will be open before your test.Toilets are available on request, eventhe waiting room is closed.Will my car be cleaned before I use it You must clean the inside of your car before your test.This means:- tidying any unnecessary items away from the dashboard, footwells, door pockets, cup holders and seats- wiping down the dashboard and car controlsThe examiner will do an additional clean of some surfaces.The car you use for your test must have at least one window open on each side throughout the test.WhatI have coronavirus symptoms Do not go to your driving test :- you or someone you live with has COVID- symptoms- yoursquove been told to self-isolate by NHS Test and Trace or the NHS COVID- app- yoursquore quarantining because you recently entered the UKChange your test appointment or cancel your testyoursquore not able to go. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: pupils benefit thinking like da vinci researchers say
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityEducationalists from Cambridge University and Edinburgh University say children would benefit from science and the arts being taught together instead of in subject silos.They say this could be done around themes such as climate change or food security.The model draws inspiration from Renaissance polymaths like Da Vinci, who worked across disciplinary boundaries in pursuit of deeper knowledge.An academic paper, published in the journal Curriculum Perspectives, cites a case study at an Aberdeen primary school, where children showed a deeper understanding of food security and environmental protection issues after learning to grow food in their school grounds.Pam Burnard, professor of arts, creativities and education at the University of Cambridge, said: ldquoIf we look at the amazing designs that Da Vinci produced, itrsquos clear he was combining dferent disciplines to advance knowledge and solve problems.ldquoWe need to encourage children to think in a similar way because tomorrowrsquos adults will have to problem-solve dferently due to the existential crises they will face: especially those of climate, sustainability, and the precarity of le on Earth.Dr Laura Colucci-Gray, of the University of Edinburghrsquos School of Education and Sport, said: ldquoThe nature of these problems calls for a radically dferent approach to knowledge.ldquoWe are proposing a move from the idea of a curriculum as something children are just lsquogivenrsquo to a curriculum lsquoin-the-makingrsquo, in response to transformations that will define their lives.In their alternative model, researchers suggest giving schools greater freedom to determine how to meet general study targets set by the curriculum.Teachers and leadership teams would make collective decisions and share practices about how to engage pupils with unying, cross-curricular themes, such as environmental sustainability.     Any attempt to reimagine education along transdisciplinary lines, with subjects being taught together, would require childrenrsquos attainment to be measured dferently, the researchers noted.Prof Burnard said: ldquoIt would require a system of testing which measures how children are internalising ideas and what they are expressing ndash not just what they know.ldquoThat may be an uncomfortable idea for some, but it is the sort of radical thinking we neededucation is going to prepare young people for the future..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Pupils would benefit from thinking like Da Vinci, researchers say article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: asylum seekers placed hotels face dehumanising treatment   report
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Refugee Council said it was ldquodeeply concerned about the accounts and experiences it has heard after speaking to hundreds of asylum seekers who are in such accommodation in the UK while awaiting a decision on their claims.The charity said some have routinely lacked ldquobasic essentials such as shoes and coats, have been confined to their rooms for days on end while waiting for their one set of clothing to be cleaned, and have been left unable to access even basic healthcare despite many having complex health needs.According to the findings, there has been a decline in mental health as a result, leading some to ldquoself-harm and experience suicidal thoughts.There have been around , asylum seekers housed in about  hotels during the pandemic, Home Office officials previously told MPs.The department resorted to putting more people into hotels when the Covid- outbreak took hold and lockdown was imposed while routine accommodation was full.Last month Home Secretary Priti Patel said the departmentrsquos aim is to have stopped using hotels by the summer.Concerns were also raised about the quality of food available and a lack of internet limiting access to legal advice, education and health information.Examples highlighted included instances where a man with kidney problems did not have sufficient access to drinking water and someone who struggled to walk being placed on the higher floor of a hotel without a lt, according to the charity.Chief executive Enver Solomon said: ldquoPeople who have fled war and persecution often arrive in the UK with just the clothes on their back, in urgent need of healthcare, nutritious food and other essentials such as toiletries.ldquoItrsquos appalling that they have had to suffer so much as a result of what to them feels like being abandoned in inappropriate accommodation with inadequate support for many weeks or months.     ldquoThe Home Office should have anticipated these basic needs and made sure they were provided for the children and adults in their care.ldquoTo prevent this dehumanising treatment from continuing, we call on ministers to promise that every person seeking asylum receives appropriate support, including access to healthcare, basic clothing and essential services.ldquoPeople seeking asylum should be able to live in dignity, rather than in conditions that worsen their health and wellbeing.A Home Office spokesperson said: ldquoAs part of our new plan for immigration, the use of hotels to accommodate new arrivals will end and we plan to introduce new asylum reception centres.ldquoThe use of hotels to temporarily accommodate people was necessary to help safely manage demands on the asylum estate during the pandemic.ldquoAsylum seekers who would otherwise be destitute are provided with accommodation, a choice of three meals a day in line with NHS nutrition guidelines, as well as access to fresh fruit and drinking water and we work closely with our providers and local charities to provide other basics..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: cummings political maverick never far controversy
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communitySources at No  have pointed the finger at him for leaking messages from Boris Johnson, claiming Mr Cummings is ldquobitter following his exit from Downing Street last year.But to his admirers, Mr Cummings is the maverick genius who overturned conventional wisdom to deliver one of the biggest political shocks in decades in the Brexit referendum.He then spent  turbulent months as the power behind the throne in No  before falling from favour. vw,vw,px, px"Dominic Cummings explaining his trip to County Durham during an extraordinary press conference Even after leaving Downing Street last year, following a power struggle involving the Prime Ministerrsquos fiancee Carrie Symonds, Mr Cummings continued to leave no doubt about his open hostility to parts of the British political system.Appearing before MPs in March he claimed the Department of Health and Social Care was reduced to a ldquosmoking ruin when the coronavirus pandemic hit.And he told MPs: ldquoAs the country emerges from lockdown there should be an urgent, very, very hard look by this buildingat what went wrong and why in .One of the key lessons to come out of the crisis was the need to go to ldquoextreme s to try to de-bureaucratise the normal system ndash a key theme in his political philosophy.It was the coronavirus crisis that thrust the man who spent most of his career operating behind the scenes into the spotlight, through his infamous trip to Barnard Castle in apparent breach of lockdown rules.The visit, and his claim he simply wanted to test his eyesight after recovering from coronavirus, attracted such attention that police complained it was undermining their efforts to enforce the regulations. vw,vw,px, px"Barnard Castle, County Durham, the scene of Mr Cummingsrsquo notorious day trip      But Mr Cummings was no stranger to controversy before his ill-fated drive in County Durham.As a special adviser to Michael Gove in the coalition government, his propensity for engaging in political scraps, particularly with the Toriesrsquo Liberal Democrat partners, caused David Cameron to describe him as a ldquocareer psychopath and seek to bar him from Whitehall.He was however to emerge as the former prime ministerrsquos nemesis in the Brexit referendum of , when he was appointed director of the official Vote Leave campaign.It was a role later portrayed in Channel  drama Brexit: The Uncivil War, in which he was played by Benedict Cumberbatch.From the off his tactics were controversial. He ordered the campaign bus to be emblazoned with the disputed claim that leaving the EU would save pound million a week to spend on the NHS.Critics complained that the figure failed to take into account the funding the UK received back from Brussels, but Mr Cummings was only too well aware that the controversy simply served to highlight the sums Britain was sending the EU. vw,vw,px, px"Benedict Cumberbatch played Dominic Cummings in a Channel  drama about Brexit He was credited with devising the ldquoTake back control slogan which was seen to capture the mood of disillusionment which helped drive the Brexit vote.And he was responsible also for a final online advertising blitz highlighting a potential influx of immigrants from TurkeyBritain remained in the EU, even though there was no imminent prospect of the country joining the bloc.He later wrote thatMr Gove and Boris Johnson, who were fronting the campaign, had not ldquopicked up the baseball bat marked lsquoTurkey NHS pound millionrsquo with five weeks to go the result could have gone the other way.Through it all, Mr Cummings made no secret of his contempt for the senior Tories on the Vote Leave board, complaining they would prefer to spend weekends off with their girlfriends than the hard business of campaigning.There was therefore consternation among many at Westminster when Mr Johnson became prime minister in July  and chose Mr Cummings to head up his No  operation.Whitehall was given an early taste of how he would operate when he fired Sonia Khan, a special adviser to then chancellor Sajid Javid, and had her marched out of Downing Street by an armed police officer for alleged leaks. vw,vw,px, px"Dominic Cummings in Downing Street With Parliament deadlocked over Brexit, he was seen as the author of the plan to prorogue its sittings, subsequently ruled unlawful by the Supreme Court, and the purge of the One Nation Tories who refused to back Mr Johnsonrsquos deal for leaving the EU.When the Prime Minister finally secured the general election he craved, it was Mr Cummings who came up with another simple but brutally effective slogan ndash ldquoGet Brexit done ndash which helped propel him to an -seat majority.With the Governmentrsquos position finally secure, Mr Cummings set about some of his pet projects, including an overhaul of the machinery of government, warning there was a ldquohard rain coming for Whitehall.A long-standing critic of what he regarded as the Oxbridge mentality which dominated the upper echelons of the civil service, he appealed for ldquoweirdos and misfits with odd skills to transform the way the country was run.He was certainly happy to cultivate the image of himself as the outsider, turning up to work in Downing Street in ill-fitting jeans and scruffy jumpers rather than traditional suit and tie..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Cummings: a political maverick never far from title: call for new strategy to restore our woodlands
story: Almac plans packaging facility   New filling station and hot food bar proposed for Craigavon workersNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoHomes and GardensLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessNewsCall for new strategy to restore our woodlandsCalls have been made for a new strategy to restore our local woodlands.By Carmel RobinsonWednesday, st April , : pm  "       "  It follows ‘ground-breaking’ research on NI forests by the Woodland Trust.SDLP MLA Dolores Kelly, sponsor of draft Environment and Nature Restoration legislation at Stormont, said that the scarcity of local woodlands is contributing to a bioersity crisis.Party colleague Patsy McGlone MLA, a member of the Stormont Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs Committee, called for a new strategy to incentivise greater numbers of land managers to invest in ecosystem services.Dolores Kelly .Mrs Kelly said: “Woodland coverage in Northern Ireland is among the worst across these islands.“Our forests and wooded areas provide a much needed break from our increasingly urbanised lives and there’s no doubt that, over the last  months, people have started to reconnect with our natural environment.“But woodlands are primarily an important habitat for plant and animal species that are being squeezed by human encroachment. “It is a shocking assessment that just % of land here is forest. “The stripping back of what was once a temperate rainforest in this part of the world is creating a severe bioersity crisis that needs to be addressed immediately,” said Mrs Kelly.“That is why I am seeking to give statutory underpinning to bioersity targets that will include the restoration of our rich woodlands.”Mr McGlone said: “Woodlands are incredibly important as a habitat and source of bioersity, particularly in rural communities. “But they also provide an important way to absorb excess carbon in our atmosphere, helping to address the climate crisis.“The Executive should urgently consider a robust new strategy to incentivise land managers to invest in ecosystem services, like managing woodlands to increase our carbon sequestration capacity. “As the future of land management remains in flux as a result of Brexit, we have an opportunity to invest in ecologically positive practice that restores nature and secures the future of rural businesses,” said the Mid Ulster SDLP MLA.‘Shock’ as leline for troubled Co Armagh medical practice is withdrawn Read full story here--Editor’s Message:Thank you for reading this article. title: dozens of pupils sent home after positive covid test at ni college

Lurgan College. Photo courtesy of Google.“I have assured parents that I have sought and followed the most up-to-date advice from the Public Health Agency .“I appreciate the concerns of parents, pupils and the wider school community and I have reassured them that every precaution has been taken in line with advice from PHA.“Ensuring the safety of pupils and staff remains the school’s absolute priority.”Horror as bags of dead lambs found during evening stroll Read full story here--Editor’s Message:Thank you for reading this article. title: phone first before going to emergency department
story: Man arrested after reports of car driving erratically near M junction   Homophobic graffiti in Lurgan condemned by AllianceNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoHomes and GardensLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessNewsPeople‘Phone first’ before going to Emergency DepartmentWith lockdown restrictions lting and more leisure activities resuming, the Southern Trust is reminding people with urgent but not critical symptoms to ‘Phone first’ before attending Emergency Departments or Minor Injuries services.By The NewsroomWednesday, st April , : pm  "       "  Patients, including children, considering attending Emergency Departments or the Minor Injuries Services at Craigavon, Daisy Hill or South Tyrone Hospital with an urgent but not le threatening injury or illness should Phone     Monday to Friday am to pm.The ‘Phone first’ approach aims to help those patients fit to ‘walk in’ to the Emergency Department , get the most appropriate care as quickly as possible and avoid busy waiting rooms. When you ring the number, a call handler takes your details. A Senior Nurse, Physiotherapist or GP will then call you back and advise on the most suitable care. For some patients, they will advise how to self-manage their condition or direct them to their community pharmacist. Those who need urgent assessment or treatment may receive an appointment with a Physiotherapist, an urgent care GP, or could be referred to another service like Minor Injuries or their own GP.Craigavon Area Hospital. Pic by PACEMAKER PRESSDr Rosemary Sloan, Clinical Lead for Urgent Care in the Southern Health and Social Care Trust explains: “The COVID- pandemic has created unprecedented challenges across health and social care, highlighting the importance of working together to improve access to our services and prioritise those who need them most. “With increasing numbers of patients attending unscheduled care services in recent weeks, for everyone’s safety and to reduce the potential spread of infection amongst both patients and staff, we must do our very best to minimise footfall and promote social distancing in all health care facilities.“Since we opened the ‘Phone First’ telephone line, only about one third of patients who call the number need to attend the Emergency Department whilst we have been able redirect others to a more suitable service, avoiding a potential y wait in a busy waiting room.“As alwaysyou think the symptoms are potentially critical, like a heart attack, stroke, or major trauma, please do not delay in phoning an ambulance or getting the patient to the Emergency Departmentyou can.“For everyone , please phone first for advice and support to find the best place to treat your condition.”Editor’s message:Thank you for reading this article. We’re more reliant on your support than ever as the sht in consumer habits brought about by Coronavirus impacts our advertisers.Please consider purchasing a copy of the paper.
